awd_abstract_narration:
Statistical physics provides an immensely useful set of tools to analyze natural phenomena involving complex interacting systems whose dynamics is difficult to describe exactly, but whose average behavior is amenable to analysis. It has found applications far beyond the realm of physics. To gain a deeper understanding of the mathematical underpinnings of this theory, it is necessary to study simplified models that nevertheless exhibit rich behavior similar to physical systems. This research project will study one class of such simplified discrete models, percolation models. In a separate topic area, probabilistic tools inspired by statistical physics will be applied to differential equations, to analyze the long-time behavior of their solutions.

The project will study the behavior of metrics of physical significance, including the chemical distance and the effective resistance in critical random environments, such as Bernoulli percolation and oriented percolation in low dimensions. These metrics are of central importance for the study of random walks, for instance. Separately, the project will also study the behavior of nonlinear Hamiltonian partial differential and stochastic differential equations with random initial data, especially data chosen from invariant and quasi-invariant measures of Gibbs type. These objects allow for the construction of special solutions with improved long-time behavior compared to the generic case. The principal investigator will participate in the organization of summer schools, as well as the design and teaching of classes on statistical mechanics of both lattice systems like percolation, and continuous dynamical systems like partial differential equations with random data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mathematical statistical mechanics studies physical systems using probability theory, the mathematics of random processes. Randomness can appear in different guises, either as a simplifying assumption to understand complex systems with many degrees of freedom, or to model "disorder", small imperfections appearing unpredictably at microscopic scales, but with regular distribution on large scales.


This award supported research in mathematical statistical mechanics, along two main lines of inquiry: dispersive equations with random initial conditions and percolative systems.


Nonlinear wave propagation phenomena are modeled by differential equations whose solutions are difficult to compute or describe after a long time. One way around this difficulty is to attempt to describe average features of the solutions. This is where the tools of probability and statistical mechanics are useful. This award supported three projects by the PI on the probabilistic (average) behavior of solutions of nonlinear wave equations, including a breakthrough paper with Oh and Tolomeo on the structure of a family of special random initial conditions.


Percolation is a simplified model of the flow of fluid through a porous medium, where local defects blocking the fluid are assumed to appear at random on a lattice. Percolation and variants of the model have become a central paradigm in mathematical statistical mechanics because of the simple definition of the model, which nevertheless exhibits complex behavior, including a phase transition. This award supported research on the structure of percolation on high-dimensional lattices, near the phase transition, including macroscopic distances in the random medium, a question of great physical importance.

Funds from this award also contributed to the training and career development of two PhD students at Cornell University. These two new doctorates are specialists are now specialists in probability theory, an area of crucial importance in an economy increasingly based on data-driven algorithms and artificial intelligence.
